title: Keeping up with the Indiana Joneses: More Brits than ever before embarking on risky pursuits while on holiday (and the over-65s are getting in on the action too)
text:
View
comments
Holidaymakers are more adventurous than ever before, with more than a third of Brits saying that they take on more daring activities while on holiday than they did even a decade earlier.
In fact, millions of travel insurance policies have had to be updated to keep up with the growing travel trend, which now includes activities such as 'cave tubing' and husky sledge driving.
And it has even led to one-upmanship between regular travellers trying to outdo each other in what insurers at Virgin Money describe as 'keeping up with the Indiana Joneses.'
Holidaymakers have been found to be more adventurous than ever, with a third of Brits taking on more daring activities while on holiday than ever before
The travel insurance arm of the finance giant now lists 46 sports, hobbies and even seemingly innocuous pastimes like archaeology as being covered by its policies.
And some carry potential physical danger, such as sand boarding and both white water and black water rafting.

Heathrow chaos: Passengers forced to board flights without... Other 'risky' activities on the list may not be so obvious, such as amateur football referees and playing badminton.
In a survey of 1,000 adults for Virgin Money Travel Insurance, British holidaymakers of all ages were shown to be getting more adventurous to compete with the exploits of their friends.
Experts at Virgin Money Travel insurance refer to this trend of travellers attempting to outdo each other as 'keeping up with the Indiana Joneses'
It found 63 per cent of 18-25-year-olds will choose to take part in such activities while away, perhaps spurred by what they've seen friends post of social media.
But one in five of the over-65s also claims to be more adventurous now than they were ten years ago.
And although they may not be running from boulders or battling Nazis, a growing number of the over-65s do follow some of the exploits of Indiana Jones, the survey found.
This includes 51 per cent visiting ancient temples, 20 per cent crossing a rope bridge, nine per cent handling snakes on holiday and two per cent gone on archaeological digs.
Millions of travel insurance policies have had to be updated to keep up with the growing travel trend, and now include activities such as 'cave tubing' and sand boarding (pictured)
Virgin Money director of banking Darrell Evans said: 'Indiana Jones remains a role-model to many holidaymakers in the UK.
'We've designed our travel policies with intrepid adventurers in mind, although they're also suitable for people who like to relax on holiday rather than battle the forces of darkness while hunting for the Holy Grail.'
The moves by Virgin Money echo a growing trend across the travel insurance industry to persuade more people to take out policies when going abroad.
Recent research by ABTA, the Association of British Travel Agents, found that around one in five people travel abroad without travel insurance.
This increases to over a third when it comes to the under-35s, with many believing that insurance is an unnecessary additional cost when planning a holiday.
